Option A. Germ cell tumor: Germ cell tumors typically arise in the reproductive organs (testes or ovaries) or occasionally outside these locations (extragonadal). It is not typically a primary bone tumor and doesn't fit the radiographic pattern.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone and can cause fever, pain, and elevated ESR, mimicking the symptoms of this case. However, osteomyelitis is more likely to show a solid periosteal reaction or sequestra on x-ray. Osteomyelitis may look similar clinically but rarely shows onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is another malignant bone tumor that commonly presents with a sunburst appearance and Codman’s triangle on x-ray. However, osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis (the wide part at the ends of bones), particularly in the distal femur or proximal tibia, rather than the diaphysis. It usually presents with pain and swelling but not systemic signs like fever and high ESR to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing’s sarcoma typically presents in the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents, with a onion skin periosteal reaction seen on x-ray.

choices.text: Initiate an insulin intravenous infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Give an insulin stat dose of 0.1 units/kg intravenously, followed by an infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Administer normal saline for the first hour followed by insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Continue with intravenous fluids without insulin administration

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a known history of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus presents to the emergency department with symptoms of increased thirst, frequent urination, abdominal pain, and confusion. On examination, the child appears dehydrated and is breathing rapidly. Laboratory tests reveal a blood glucose level of 400 mg/dl and blood gas analysis is indicative of acidosis. Initial treatment with intravenous fluids has been started. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer normal saline for the first hour followed by insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour

 

The clinical presentation is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is an acute, life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus that typically requires IV fluids and insulin administration to correct hyperglycemia and halt ketogenesis. According to latest guidelines for management of DKA in children first IV fulids are administered for one hour, then insulin is adminsitered by IV infusion at a rate of 0.1 U/kg/hour. 

Other options:

Option B. Give an insulin stat dose of 0.1 units/kg intravenously, followed by an infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: According to new guidelines, bolus dose of insulin is not used for treatment of DKA particularly in children as it increases the risk of cerebral edema in many children.

 

Option A. Initiate an insulin intravenous infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin infusion is an essential part of DKA management, according to new guidelines, it's typically given one hour after the adminsitration of IV fluids.

 

Option D. Continue with intravenous fluids without insulin administration: This would not address the hyperglycemia and ketosis and is therefore inadequate for the treatment of DKA.

 

Educational Objective:

According to latest guidelines for management of DKA in children first IV fulids are administered for one hour, then insulin is adminsitered by IV infusion at a rate of 0.1 U/kg/hour.

choices.text: Calcium Channel Blocker action
Nitric oxide mediated vasodilation

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of ischemic heart disease. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5-HT agonist

 

Chest pain in an elderly woman with a history of ischemic heart disease, who is on treatment for migraine, could potentially be linked to the mechanism of action of her migraine medication. Among the options given 5-HT agonists can cause this adverse effect. Triptans and ergotamine are a group of drugs that are used in acute attacks of migraine. They act on 5HT1B/1D receptors as agonist and cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels. Therefore, they should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease as they can precipitate myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-HT Antagonist: Serotonin (5-HT) antagonists like cyproheptadine and methysergide etc are used for prophylaxis of migraine (not in treatment). These drugs are not commonly associated with causing chest pain or exacerbating ischemic heart disease.

 

Option C. Calcium Channel Blocker Action: While calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are used in migraine prophylaxis, they are generally heart-protective and used in the treatment of angina and hypertension due to their vasodilatory effects. It's unlikely that CCBs would cause chest pain.

 

Option D. Nitric Oxide Mediated Vasodilation: Nitric oxide donors (like nitrates) are used in the treatment of angina due to their vasodilatory effects. They are not typically used in migraine treatment, and their vasodilatory action would be more likely to relieve, rather than cause, ischemic chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-HT Agonist includes medications like triptans (e.g., sumatriptan), which are commonly used in migraine treatment. Triptans are 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists and can cause vasoconstriction of blood vessels. In patients with ischemic heart disease, this vasoconstriction can exacerbate angina (chest pain) or precipitate myocardial infarction, especially if the coronary arteries are already compromised.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of frequent episodes of red, painful eyes, stiffness, and back pain. He has sacroiliitis and anterior uveitis, according to the examination. Which HLA is frequently involved among the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HLA B27

 

The patient's symptoms of red painful eyes, stiffness, back pain, sacroiliitis, and anterior uveitis strongly indicates ankylosing spondylitis. 

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS (AS)

 

  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton (sacroiliac joint and spine) with variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints. 
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy. 
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Males are affected more frequently than females (2:1 to 10:1)
    • Age of onset is between 15–25 years (late adolescence and early adulthood).
    • The initial symptom is usually dull pain, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, accompanied by low back morning stiffness of few hours that improves with activity and returns following rest.
    • Question mark (?) posture can occur due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis. 
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late.
    • The most common extra-articular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis) occurring in 30%. Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
  • Diagnostic Criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria must be one of the 3:
      1. Inflammatory back pain
      2. Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) 
      3. Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).
    • Inflammatory back pain is classified if 4/5 are present
      1. Pain for > 3 months
      2. <40 years of age
      3. Insidious onset
      4. Pain improves with exercise
      5. Pain at night
  • Etiology and Pathogenesis:
    • > 90% of AS patients are HLA-B27 positive. 
    • The enthesis is the primary site of pathology particularly in pelvis and spine.
    • It is associated with prominent edema of adjacent bone marrow and is characterized by erosive lesions that eventually undergo ossification.
    • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA DR4: HLA DR4 is associated with autoimmune diseases. It is more strongly linked to rheumatoid arthritis and type 1 diabetes.

 

Option B. HLA DR3: HLA DR3 is associated with autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes, Graves' disease, and celiac disease.

 

Option C. HLA DQB1: HLA DQB1 is also linked to autoimmune diseases, particularly type 1 diabetes and celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The patient's symptoms of red painful eyes, stiffness, back pain, sacroiliitis, and anterior uveitis strongly indicates ankylosing spondylitis. 
  • HLA-B27 is strongly associated with this condition. 
  • Other HLA types are linked to various autoimmune diseases, HLA-B27 is the most strongly associated with this specific presentation.

choices.text: Drug 1 represents agonist and drug 2 represents inverse agonist﻿﻿﻿
Drug 3 represents agonist and drug 4 represents inverse agonist
﻿﻿﻿Drug 1 represents agonist and drug 4 represents inverse agonist
﻿﻿﻿Drug 2 represents partial agonist and drug 3 represents inverse agonist

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding the given graph?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Drug 1 represents agonist and drug 4 represents inverse agonist

 

Drug 1 = Full agonist, showing the maximal effect, having an intrinsic efficacy of +1

 

E.g., Salbutamol is a β2 receptor agonist

 

Drug 2 = Partial agonist, produces submaximal effect and has an intrinsic efficacy in the range of 0 to +1. E.g., Buprenorphine at the opioid receptors.

 

Drug 3 = Antagonist, having no effect of its own at the receptor, that is an intrinsic efficacy of 0.

 

E.g., Naltrexone and Naloxone at the opioid receptors.

 

Drug 4 = Inverse agonist, produces opposite effect and has a negative intrinsic efficacy.

 

E.g., Beta-Carboline is an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug 1: Shows the highest level of response, indicating it is a full agonist.

 

Drug 2: Shows a submaximal response, indicating it is a partial agonist.

 

Drug 3: Shows no change in response, indicating it is an antagonist.

 

Drug 4: Shows a negative response, indicating it is an inverse agonist.

questions.text: What to be done next? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bone biopsy

 

  • The given X-ray image shows a bone tumor which needs to be diagnosed.
  • The image shows a well-defined, lytic lesion (a darker area indicating bone destruction) in the distal femur, specifically in the medial femoral condyle. 
  • The lesion appears somewhat expansile and has a narrow zone of transition, suggesting a benign or low-grade aggressive lesion rather than a highly aggressive malignant tumor. 
  • There's no clear periosteal reaction or soft tissue mass immediately evident.
  • This appearance is highly suggestive of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT), given its typical location (epiphyseal/metaphyseal region of long bones), lytic nature, and often eccentric appearance. 
  • Other possibilities might include an aneurysmal bone cyst or a chondroblastoma, but GCT is a strong consideration.
  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • Bone biopsy is the most appropriate "next step" to definitively diagnose the nature of the lesion before proceeding with a potentially complex surgical intervention.
  • Without a biopsy, one cannot be absolutely certain of the benign or malignant nature, or the specific type of tumor.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extended curettage with allograft. Curettage involves scraping out the tumor. "Extended" curettage aims to remove as much of the tumor as possible while preserving the bone. After removal, the resulting cavity often needs to be filled to maintain structural integrity. An allograft is one option for filling. This is a common treatment for GCTs, especially those that are not highly aggressive or are in a location where wide excision would lead to significant functional impairment. Extended curettage remains the preferred treatment option for Grade I and II GCT due to least postoperative morbidity, cost-effectiveness, and surgical convenience. The risk of recurrence is high after curettage alone,and therefore adjuvants such as cryosurgery, cement, phenol or a combination of these are recommended. 

 

Option C. Curettage. Curettage alone might be insufficient for a lesion like a GCT due to its tendency for local recurrence. Compared with resection, curettage is associated with a higher rate of local recurrence; however, curettage often allows for a better functional result. Curettage can be extended by the use of adjuvants, such as liquid nitrogen, phenol, polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA), or thermal cautery to extend destruction of tumor cells. Bone cavities have been reinforced with autologous bone grafts, allograft, PMMA bone cement, demineralized bone matrix and bone graft substitutes. These fillers augment final bone strength, reduce the risk of local recurrence (esp. giant cell tumors) and fill the empty cavities. 

 

Educational Objective:

  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • The management will follow the result of the bone biopsy. 
  • If the question implies "what is the definitive treatment generally indicated for a lesion with this appearance (strongly suggesting GCT)," then options A or D would be relevant. Giant Cell Tumors are known for local recurrence after simple curettage, which is why extended curettage (with or without adjuvant therapy) is the preferred surgical treatment.

choices.text: Protects the acid labile drug from gastric acidity
Protects the gastric mucosa from irritant effects of certain drugs
Prolongs the half-life of the drug

questions.text: Many drugs are given as enteric coated tablets. All of the following are the advantages of enteric coating of drugs EXCEPT? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prolongs the half-life of the drug

 

Enteric coatings on tablets protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and deliver drugs distal to the stomach. However, they do not prolong the half-life of a drug, which is determined by the drug's metabolism and elimination from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Enteric-coated drugs are designed with a special coating that resists dissolution in the acidic environment of the stomach. This coating dissolves instead in the more alkaline environment of the small intestine. The primary purposes of this enteric coating are:

 

Option A. Protect the acid-labile drug from gastric acidity: Some drugs are unstable in the acidic environment of the stomach and can be degraded before they have a chance to be absorbed. Enteric coating protects these drugs from the acidic gastric environment, ensuring they reach the intestine, where they can be absorbed effectively.

 

Option B. Protect the gastric mucosa from the irritant effects of certain drugs: Certain drugs can irritate the gastric mucosa, leading to discomfort or even ulcers. Enteric coating prevents these drugs from being released in the stomach, thereby reducing the risk of gastric irritation.

 

Option D. Deliver drugs distal to the stomach: Enteric coating is also used to ensure that a drug is released in the intestine rather than the stomach, which can be important for drugs that are intended to act in the intestine or are better absorbed from the intestinal lining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enteric coating is primarily used to protect acid-labile drugs from gastric acidity, protect the gastric mucosa from irritant effects, and ensure drug delivery distal to the stomach. It does not prolong the half-life of the drug.

choices.text: Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint.
Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential.
Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone.
Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy came with a tumor resembling a mushroom in the distal femur, which has been present for the last two years. What characteristics should the clinician look for to discern a potential malignant transformation? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

 

  • The provided X-ray reveals a clearly defined exostosis, indicating a diagnosis of osteochondroma.
  • Additionally, the hyaline cap thickness of 2cms observed on the MRI raises concerns about the possibility of malignant transformation.

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone.
  • It is not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.
  • It is the developmental malformation thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodules.
  • X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur.
  • Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap that is irregular and usually cannot be seen on radiographs, a result of development malformation.
  • Occasionally, calcification within the cap may be seen which usually angle away from the growth plate.
  • Typically, the cap is only a few millimeters thick in adults, although it may be 2 cm thick in a child.
  • An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity.
  • Osteochondromas are found on the metaphysis of a long bone near the physis.
  • They are seen most often on the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation.
  • Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; has enlarged further after skeletal maturity, there is loss of corticomedullary differentiation.
  • It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma.
  • In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick. (Best evaluated by MRI).
  • Osteochondromas are of two types: Pedunculated and broad- based or sessile.
  • Pedunculated tumors are more common. The stalk is directed away from the physis adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the parent bone.
  • The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap
  • Treatment: 
    • Surgery (en bloc resection-extraperiosteal resection) is indicated for lesion that causes pain, symptomatic impingement on neurovascular structure, compromise of joint function, cosmetic deformity, painful bursa formation and rapid increase in size of lesion or when imaging features suggest malignancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint. This is not true for an osteochondroma. The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap which is irregular and usually grows away from the growth plate.

 

Option B. Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential. This is not true. The incidence of malignant degeneration is approximately 1% for patients with a solitary osteochondroma and 6% for patients with multiple hereditary exostoses. Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; any further enlargement after skeletal maturity takes place, loss of corticomedullary differentiation takes place. It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma. In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick which can be best evaluated by MRI).

 

Option C. Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone. This is not true. The stalk of the lesion grows away from the physis, adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the corresponding components of the parent bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The malignant transformation of osteochondroma is suspected when the hyaline cap thickness is 2cm, as seen on the MRI.

questions.text: A hospital is investigating the effectiveness of statins in a multiple-centric clinical trial. The study involves 4000-5000 patients and half of them have received the drug while the other half was given a placebo. Both the subjects and the investigators are unaware of which group is getting the drug and which group is being administered the placebo. Which of the following phases of clinical trial corresponds to this scenario? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phase 3  


As the study is being conducted in multiple centers in a double blinded manner, where neither the physician nor the patients know what they are receiving, therefore this trial is in Phase 3.

 

The phases of clinical trials are as follows: -

 

 

  • Phase Zero trials are called micro-dosing studies. It is an optional trial done by some companies on small number of healthy volunteers to know the pharmacokinetics of the drug. Dose used is one-hundredth of the final human dose or 100 microgram (whichever is lower).
  • Pre-clinical trials are animal studies. The drugs are first tested on the small animals like rats, guinea pig etc. to know the complete pharmacokinetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The described clinical trial, with its large sample size, multiple centers, double-blind design, and focus on confirming the efficacy of statins, corresponds to a Phase 3 clinical trial. This phase is crucial for determining whether the drug is effective and safe for widespread use.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to your clinic with the following deformity of the right arm. Which is the most likely fracture leading to such a defect? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar fracture

 

SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURE OF THE HUMERUS

 

  • This is one of the most serious fractures in childhood as it is often associated with complications. 
  • Most common elbow fractures – 50-70%
  • Mechanism:
    • The fracture is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand. 
    • As the hand strikes the ground, the elbow is forced into hyperextension resulting in fracture of the humerus above the condyles. 
  • Pathoanatomy:
    • The fracture line extends transversely through the distal metaphysis of humerus just above the condyles. 
  • Types:
    • A supracondylar fracture may be of extension or flexion type, depending upon the displacement of the distal fragment. 
    • The extension type is the commoner (98%) of the two. 
    • In this, the distal fragment is extended (tilted backwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
    • In the flexion type, the distal fragment is flexed (tilted forwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction and cast
    • If conservative management fails or if fracture is displaced, closed reduction and K-wire fixation is done.
  • Complications:
    • Malunion – most common 
    • Posteromedial displacement develops cubitus varus/gunstock deformity
    • Nerve injury: Anterior interosseous nerve most commonly injured followed by median, radial and ulnar nerves – transient neuropraxia occurs 
    • Vessel injury: Brachial artery 
    • Volkmann’s ischemia and compartment syndrome 
    • Elbow stiffness 
    • Myositis ossificans 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corti-cocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension. It is one of the most common fractures in elderly. It is commonly associated with dinner fork deformity. It is treated successfully with a hand-shaking cast. Finger stiffness is the most common complication. Malunion is the 2nd most common complication, leading to dinner fork deformity. Colle’s fracture is the commonest cause of sudeck’s dystrophy in the upper limb. 

 

 

Option B. Lateral epicondyle fracture. Lateral humeral condyle fractures are the second most commonly encountered elbow fractures after supracondylar fractures in the pediatric age group. These fractures are intra-articular and are prone to displacement owing to the attachment of the forearm extensor muscles on the lateral condyle. Due to this, they can produce various complications, including elbow deformity, if not appropriately managed. Displaced fractures are at a higher risk of non-union. Malunion, cubitus varus, avascular necrosis, and post-operative infection are recognized complications following surgery. The most common mechanism is a fall on the outstretched hand with the elbow in extension and the forearm in supination. Fractures with <2mm displacement can have conservative treatment. The indications of surgery are fracture displacement >2 mm and articular surface incongruency. Closed reduction and percutaneous fixation are options.

 

 

Option C. Medial epicondyle fracture. A medial epicondyle fracture is an avulsion injury of the attachment of the common flexors of the forearm. The injury is usually extra-articular but can be sometimes associated with an elbow dislocation. Medial epicondyle fractures are common and account for 10% of all elbow fractures in children. They occur between the ages of 7-15 years. They are usually a result from an avulsion injury caused by a valgus stress at the elbow and contraction of the flexor muscles. Potential complications include medial elbow instability and nonunion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows a gunstock deformity i.e., cubitus varus deformity of the elbow after malunion of the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

choices.text: Matzke scale
Salazar scale
Rummack-mathew scale

questions.text: Vancomycin nomogram is known as (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Matzke scale

 

The Vancomycin nomogram is also known as the Matzke nomogram or the Matzke scale. It is a tool used to help predict the appropriate dose of vancomycin, an antibiotic, based on the patient's creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration. The nomogram is a graphical representation that allows healthcare providers to quickly and easily determine the optimal dose of vancomycin for a given patient, taking into account factors such as kidney function and the patient's weight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salazar scale: This nomogram is not related to vancomycin dosing. It is used to predict overall survival of patients with cancer.

 

Option C. Rummack-Matthew scale: This is used to assess potential hepatotoxicity after acetaminophen intake based on serum acetaminophen concentration.

 

Option D. Krutzko scale: There is no widely recognized medical scale or nomogram known as the Krutzko scale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vancomycin nomogram, also known as the Matzke scale, is a crucial tool for determining the appropriate dosing of vancomycin based on creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration, ensuring both efficacy and safety in patient treatment.

choices.text: CO2 retention due to opioid use

questions.text:
A patient presented with pelvic fracture and head trauma after a road traffic accident.

He was given IV morphine for pain relief following which he developed respiratory difficulty. What could be the most likely cause? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 retention due to opioid use


The development of respiratory difficulty in a patient who received IV morphine for pain relief after sustaining a pelvic fracture and head trauma can be due to several reasons.

 

Opioids like morphine can depress the respiratory center in the brain, leading to decreased respiratory rate and tidal volume. This can result in CO2 retention and respiratory difficulty, particularly in higher doses or in patients with pre-existing respiratory issues. This is a well-known side effect of opioids and is a common cause of respiratory depression following opioid administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic Fracture: While a pelvic fracture can be severe and cause significant pain, it is not typically directly associated with the development of respiratory difficulty unless there are associated injuries, such as a pneumothorax or hemorrhage leading to shock.

 

Option C. Cerebral Edema: Head trauma can lead to cerebral edema, which in turn can affect the brain's respiratory center. However, the onset of respiratory difficulty immediately following opioid administration suggests that the opioid's effects are more likely to be the cause, rather than a progression of cerebral edema, which usually develops over a longer period.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Embolism: A pulmonary embolism (PE) is a possible complication following trauma and immobilization. However, the immediate onset of respiratory difficulty after opioid administration makes PE less likely as the primary cause in this scenario.

 

Considering the timing and circumstances, the most likely cause of the respiratory difficulty in this patient is CO2 Retention due to Opioid Use. Morphine and other opioids can cause respiratory depression, leading to reduced ventilation and CO2 retention.

 

  • The CO2 retention can also increase the ICP. Apart from that, miosis is produced by morphine, which makes it difficult for assessment of neurological status in head trauma patients. Therefore, morphine is contraindicated in head injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opioids like morphine can cause respiratory depression by decreasing the respiratory rate and tidal volume, leading to CO2 retention. This effect is particularly concerning in patients with head trauma due to the potential for increased intracranial pressure.

choices.text: Safety in pregnancy
Dose adjustment in renal failure
Cost ratio from cheap to expensive
As per safety or therapeutic index

questions.text: Category A, B, C, D, X in drug classification is indicative of which of the following?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Safety in pregnancy

 

The categories A, B, C, D, and X are used to classify drugs based on their safety during pregnancy. This classification helps in determining the potential risk of medications to the fetus when taken during pregnancy.

 

Pregnancy drug category, which are indicative of their safety are as follows:

 

Category A > B > C > D > X

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dose adjustment in renal failure: Drug classifications for dose adjustments in renal failure typically involve guidelines based on the drug's pharmacokinetics and renal clearance. These guidelines are not categorized as A, B, C, D, X.

 

Option C. Cost ratio from cheap to expensive: Drug classifications based on cost are not typically denoted by the categories A, B, C, D, X. Cost-related classifications might be discussed in economic terms or based on generic versus brand name distinctions.

 

Option D. As per safety or therapeutic index: The therapeutic index of a drug, which measures its safety margin, is not categorized using the A, B, C, D, X system. The therapeutic index is a ratio comparing the toxic dose to the therapeutic dose, but it is not classified in this alphabetical manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of drugs into categories A, B, C, D, and X is specifically used to indicate their safety during pregnancy, helping healthcare providers to make informed decisions about medication use in pregnant patients.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is diagnosed with breast cancer. Her tumor is found to be HER2-positive but estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative. The tumor was resistant to trastuzumab. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be effective in the treatment of this patient's breast cancer?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lapatinib

 

Lapatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that can be used for the treatment of HER2-positive but trastuzumab-resistant breast cancer. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that is commonly used for the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer, but some patients may develop resistance to this drug over time. Lapatinib works by targeting the HER2 receptor, which is overexpressed in HER2-positive breast cancer, and can be effective in treating breast cancer that has become resistant to trastuzumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sorafenib is a kinase inhibitor that is primarily used for the treatment of advanced liver cancer and kidney cancer. It works by blocking the activity of several proteins that promote the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Option C. Vismodegib is a hedgehog pathway inhibitor that is used for the treatment of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer. It works by blocking the hedgehog signalling pathway, which is involved in the development and growth of cancer cells.

 

Option D. Erlotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that is used for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, pancreatic cancer, and other types of cancer. It works by blocking the activity of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which is involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lapatinib is an effective treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer, especially in cases where the cancer has become resistant to trastuzumab. It works by targeting the HER2 receptor and can help manage this specific type of breast cancer.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple swelling in hand & wrist. Finger X-ray is given. Identify: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple enchondromatosis

 

ENCHONDROMA

 

  • When chondromas arise in the medullary canal, they’re referred to as enchondroma.
  • Enchondroma is benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand.
  • They are seen after age of skeletal maturity.
  • These are the centric, non-expansile or minimally expansile tumors with marginal sclerosis.
  • Medullary cavity, Metaphysical tumour

 

 

  • Most common tumour of bones of hand and feet
  •  5% premalignant
  • Multiple enchondromas is also known as Ollier’s syndrome. There are multiple enchondromas all over the body.
  • Multiple enchondromas + subcutaneous Hemangioma + Phlebolith (Calcified superficial veins) = Maffucci syndrome

 

 

Maffucci syndrome: A) Hemangiomas, B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in < 2% solitary cases, 30% in ollier disease and 100% in maffucci’s syndrome.
  • Treatment: Extended Curettage + bone grafting

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple brown tumor. It has been reported that 2-5% patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have brown tumor (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Bone brown tumor secondary to primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is very rare, which is caused by massive secretion of PTH. First, a large amount of bone calcium is mobilized into blood, resulting in fibrous tissue hyperplasia in bone and leaky hemorrhage. Then, macrophage reactive hyperplasia resulted in phagocytosis of red blood cells and a large amount of hemosiderin is produced, thereby forming a brown nodule. The lesions are usually multiple, most commonly seen in ribs, clavicle, pelvis, long bones and mandibles while others are rare. The radiograph of brown tumor is often characterized by osteoporosis, thinning of cortical bone and multiple localized cystic bone destruction.

 

 

Option C. Multiple osteophytic growth. Osteophytes are cartilage-capped bony proliferations that most commonly develop at the margins of a synovial joint as a response to articular cartilage damage, as seen very commonly in degenerative joint disease. Central osteophytes can develop from cartilage lesions within a joint. They are considered a hallmark of osteoarthritis. Osteophytes may be confused with syndesmophytes and enthesophytes. Small osteophytes are sometimes referred to as osteophytic lipping.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows multiple enchondromas in the hand.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

RICKETS

 

  • In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones.
  • Pathology:
    • Irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis
    • Thin and weak new trabeculae
    • On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped

 

 

  • Causes:
    • Vitamin D disorders: nutritional, secondary, malabsorption, decreased liver (25) hydroxylase activity
    • Calcium deficiency
    • Phosphorus deficiency
    • Renal losses: Fanconi syndrome
    • Tumors associated with rickets: GCT, osteoblastoma, fibrous dysplasia, neurofibromatosis
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis).
    • Indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance)
    • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
    • Looser’s zone in 20% cases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C. Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding).

 

 

Option C. Vitamin A. Hypovitaminosis A results from inadequate intake of vitamin A, fat malabsorption, or liver disorders and produces a variety of epithelial alterations. Radiographic features includes slow bone development, widening of cranial sutures with bulging fontanelles, and skull hyperostosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin E. Hypovitaminosis E is rare. It is usually due to the malabsorption of vitamin E, e.g. cystic fibrosis or pancreatic failure. It manifests as dysfunction of the CNS, characteristically presenting with a tremor and ataxia. Tendon reflexes are often absent. Clinically and radiologically it may be indistinguishable from the neurological sequelae of hypovitaminosis B12, i.e. subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency presents as thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis with abnormally wide (splaying), cupping or flaring (Brush-like) appearance; and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

choices.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decreased response to analgesia

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndromes, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly, compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • The pain is unrelieved with opioid analgesia.
    • In compartment syndrome, the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: Capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments.
    • Deep flexor muscles are involved, particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.
    • The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check radial pulse by displacing the cast. Pulselessness is the late feature to appear in compartment syndrome. It is not a reliable indicator for the presence of the condition.

 

Option C. Change in colour of fingers. This can occur due to vascular insufficiency but is an uncommon entity.

 

Option D. Change in odor. This is not usually observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

questions.text: Which method of measurement of scoliosis has been depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cobb’s angle

 

  • This X-ray of spine shows lateral curvature (scoliosis) and angle marked is for its measurement – Cobb’s angle.

 

COBB’S ANGLE

 

  • Most widely used measurement to quantify the magnitude of spinal scoliosis, on plain radiographs.
  • Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of >10°.
  • A Cobb angle can also aid kyphosis or lordosis assessment in the sagittal plane.
  • Measurement:
    • To measure the Cobb angle, one must first decide which vertebrae are the end vertebrae of the curve deformity (the terminal vertebrae) – the vertebra whose endplates are most tilted towards each other. 
    • Lines are then drawn along the endplates (or the pedicles if the endplates are not properly visualized), and the angle between the two lines, where they intersect, measured. 
    • In cases where the curvature is not marked, then the lines will not intersect on the film/monitor, in which case a further two lines can be plotted, each at right angles to the previous lines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kite’s angle. Kite’s angle or talocalcaneal angle is the angle between the lines drawn down the axis of the talus and calcaneus measured on weight bearing foot radiograph. This angle varies depending on the position of the calcaneus under the talus and the stiffness of the foot ligaments. Measurement: midtalar line should pass through/just medial to the base of 1st metatarsal and the mid-calcaneal line should pass through the base of 4th metatarsal. In hindfoot varus, the talocalcaneal angle is < 25⁰; in hindfoot valgus, it is > 40⁰; while in a normal foot, it is 25-40⁰.

 

 

Option C. Bohler’s angle. Tuber angle of Bohler (Tuber-joint angle) is used in the assessment of intra-articular calcaneal fractures. It is formed between a line drawn from highest points of anterior process of the calcaneus and highest point of posterior facet, and a line drawn tangentially to the superior edge of the calcaneal tuberosity. It is normally 20-40 degrees. Flattening/Reduction/Reversal of this angle indicates that the weight-bearing posterior facet has collapsed (intra-articular fracture) or Degree of proximal displacement of the tuberosity (intra-articular and extra-articular fracture both).

 

 

Option D. Gissane angle. Also known as critical angle of Gissane, it is used to evaluate the severity of calcaneal fractures. It is formed by two cortical struts extending laterally, one along the lateral margin of posterior facet and other extending to the beak of the calcaneus. Normally, it is an obtuse angle of 95-105 degree. It increases in intra-articular fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows the Cobb’s angle, which is used for the measurement of degree of lateral curvature of the spine in scoliosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with history of fever with bloody diarrhea 2 weeks back, followed by swollen, red and erythematous joints. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shigella

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS/REITER’S SYNDROME

 

  • The patient presents with a classic picture of reactive arthritis. 

  • Reactive arthritis is precipitated by antecedent gastrointestinal and genitourinary infections and manifests as an asymmetric sterile oligoarthritis, typically of the lower extremities.

  • Reactive arthritis occurs most commonly in young men and is associated with HLA-B27 in 80% of patients.

  • Etiopathogenesis:

    • Most cases of reactive arthritis develop within 1-4 weeks after either a gastrointestinal infection (usually with Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, or Campylobacter) or a sexually transmitted infection (with Chlamydia trachomatis or perhaps Ureaplasma urealyticum).

  • Clinical Features:

    • The arthritis is most commonly asymmetric and frequently involves the large weight-bearing joints (chiefly the knee and ankle). 

    • Sacroiliitis or ankylosing spondylitis is observed in at least 20% of patients, especially after frequent recurrences.

    • Triad: Arthritis + Conjunctivitis + Urethritis/Cervivitis (in females)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotavirus. Rotavirus is a common cause of viral gastroenteritis, particularly in infants and young children. Typical symptoms among children with rotavirus infection include vomiting; watery, non-bloody diarrhea; and fever. In severe cases, dehydration, seizures, and death can occur. It is not commonly associated with reactive arthritis.

 

Option C. E.coli. While some strains of E. coli (like enterohemorrhagic E. coli O157:H7) can cause bloody diarrhea, and some E. coli infections have been linked to reactive arthritis, Shigella is more classically and frequently associated with it, especially given the history of fever and bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Giardia. Giardia is a parasite that causes giardiasis, characterized by watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, gas, and abdominal cramps. It is not typically associated with reactive arthritis. Inflammatory arthritis has been described following enteric infections with Giardia sp. The interval between the preceding infection and the manifestation of arthritis is 2-4 weeks. Post-infectious arthritis has a predilection for joints of the lower limbs particularly the knee and ankle. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Joint infection can occur as a manifestation of gastrointestinal infection from pathogen Shigella. 

  • This is most commonly found, and is called reactive arthritis, which causes joint swelling, pain and erythema. 

  • It is commonly associated with HLA B27.

questions.text: Which of the following organism is intrinsically resistant to the given drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida krusei: Fluconazole

 

  • Candida krusei is known to have intrinsic resistance to fluconazole, which means that this organism generally does not respond to treatment with fluconazole. This is due to a combination of mechanisms including alterations in the target enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, efflux pump activity, and changes in membrane sterols. Therefore, for infections caused by Candida krusei, alternative antifungal agents such as amphotericin B, echinocandins, or voriconazole are typically considered.
  • In the clinical setting, the intrinsic resistance of Candida krusei to fluconazole is significant, as fluconazole is often used as a first-line agent for the treatment of Candida infections. The presence of Candida krusei may therefore necessitate a shift in the standard therapeutic approach and prompt the use of different antifungal therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus niger: Voriconazole Voriconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that is effective against most species of Aspergillus, including Aspergillus niger. It is often used as a first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis. Therefore, Aspergillus niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus: Micafungin Aspergillus fumigatus is generally susceptible to micafungin. Micafungin belongs to the echinocandin class of antifungal drugs, which are effective against most Aspergillus species, but echinocandins are not the first choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. They are typically used as second-line agents or in combination therapy for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option C. Candida glabrata: Amphotericin B Candida glabrata can be susceptible to amphotericin B, but it is known for having a dose-dependent sensitivity or a reduced susceptibility. Some strains may show resistance, but this is not considered intrinsic resistance. Instead, amphotericin B resistance in C. glabrata can be due to acquired mechanisms.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, necessitating the use of alternative antifungal agents for treatment.

choices.text: The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition
The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible
They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design
The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding suicidal inhibition? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition

 

SUICIDE INHIBTION

 

Suicide inhibition, also known as mechanism-based inhibition, is a unique and fascinating aspect of enzyme kinetics. It's a process where an enzyme binds to a substrate analogue, which initially seems like a normal substrate to the enzyme. However, as the enzyme starts to act on this 'pseudo-substrate,' a chemical reaction occurs that modifies the enzyme in such a way that it becomes irreversibly inactivated. This process is termed 'suicide' because the enzyme actively participates in its own inhibition.

 

STEPS INVOLVED IN SUICIDE INHIBITION

 

  1. Binding: The suicide substrate, which is often structurally similar to the actual substrate, binds to the enzyme's active site.
  2. Initial Reaction: The enzyme catalyses a reaction on this substrate analogue, similar to how it would act on its natural substrate.
  3. Formation of Reactive Intermediate: This reaction, however, leads to the formation of a chemically reactive intermediate. This intermediate is the key to the suicide inhibition mechanism.
  4. Modification of Enzyme: The reactive intermediate then reacts with the enzyme itself, leading to a covalent modification of the enzyme. This modification typically occurs at the active site, crucial for the enzyme's activity.
  5. Irreversible Inhibition: As a result of this modification, the enzyme is irreversibly inactivated. It can no longer bind to its natural substrate or catalyse the reaction it was designed for.
  6. Specificity: One of the key features of suicide inhibition is its specificity. Because the inhibitor is structurally similar to the natural substrate, the process is highly specific to the targeted enzyme. This makes suicide inhibitors very effective as drugs, as they can selectively target and inactivate specific enzymes in the body.

 

Other Options:

Option B. The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible: This is true. The substrate analogue binds irreversibly to the enzyme, leading to its permanent inactivation.

 

Option C. They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design: This is true. Suicide inhibitors are designed to be highly specific for the target enzyme, making them valuable in rational drug design.

 

Option D. The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it: This is true. The enzyme catalyzes the conversion of the substrate analogue to a reactive intermediate, which then irreversibly modifies the enzyme, leading to its inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLINICAL IMPORTANCE

 

Suicide inhibitors have significant implications in drug development, especially for designing drugs that target enzymes involved in disease processes. For instance, certain antibiotics work by suicide inhibition of bacterial enzymes, and some drugs used in the treatment of hypertension and depression also act through this mechanism.

 

Understanding the mechanism of suicide inhibition helps in the development of more effective and specific drugs, with fewer off-target effects. It's a powerful example of how knowledge of biochemistry can be applied in medicinal chemistry and pharmacology.

 

EXAMPLES OF SUICIDE INHIBITORS

 

  • Beta lactams (Penicillins)
  • Aspirin
  • Allopurinol
  • MAO inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in treatment of leprosy can result in hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

 

Clofazimine is known to cause hyperpigmentation of the skin. This drug is used in leprosy treatment for its anti-inflammatory properties and its ability to kill Mycobacterium leprae. Clofazimine can lead to a characteristic reddish-brown to black discoloration of the skin, which can be quite distressing to patients but is usually harmless.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Dapsone is an antibiotic commonly used in the treatment of leprosy. While it has various side effects, hyperpigmentation is not typically associated with dapsone. Common side effects include hemolysis (especially in individuals with G6PD deficiency) and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that can be used as part of alternative regimens for leprosy. Hyperpigmentation is not a known side effect of ofloxacin. Its common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and tendinitis.

 

Option C. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is another cornerstone drug in the treatment of leprosy. It can cause orange-red discoloration of body fluids (such as urine, sweat, and tears), but it does not typically cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this case, the patient's hyperpigmentation is most likely due to clofazimine. This side effect is well-documented and is a result of the drug accumulating in the skin.

choices.text: Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip.
Vascular injury is more common in anterior hip dislocation.
Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior.
In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation.

questions.text: Mark incorrect option: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve injury more common in anterior dislocation of hip.

 

 

 

  • “Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip” – this statement is incorrect. 
  • In posterior hip dislocations, the sciatic nerve is at significant risk of injury. This is the most common nerve injury associated with hip dislocations.
  • In anterior hip dislocations, the femoral nerve or obturator nerve can be injured, but these are generally less common than sciatic nerve injury in posterior dislocations.
  • Therefore, stating nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation is false as it is more common in posterior dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vascular injury more common in anterior hip dislocation. This statement is correct. This is so because the femoral vessels are in close proximity to the hip joint anteriorly, so there are more chances of vascular injury to occur from anterior hip dislocation. Major vascular injuries are rare in both anterior and posterior dislocations. 

 

Option C. Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior. This statement is correct. The incidence of posterior dislocation of hip is around 90%. This is because of the greater strength of anterior ligaments than the posterior ones. 

 

Option D. In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation. This statement is true. The position of the limb when a patient presents with posterior hip dislocation is of Flexion, Adduction and Internal Rotation i.e., FADIR while in anterior dislocation, it is FABER i.e., Flexion, Abduction and External Rotation. 

 

 

FADIR in posterior hip dislocation

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anterior dislocation of hip, vascular injuries are more common whereas in posterior dislocation, nerve injury (particularly sciatic nerve) is more common.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The matrix forming the tumor is the cause of calcification.
  • It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma.
  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • It occurs more frequently in males than in females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Characteristic histological feature is malignant cells with osteoid formation. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.
  • Osteosarcoma is the most common radiation-induced sarcoma.
  • Clinical features:
    • Almost all patients report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis, seen in 25% of patients
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.

 

 

Codman’s triangle

 

  • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.

 

 

  • MRI is the best test to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue and to determine the relationship of the tumor to nearby anatomical structures.
  • A bone scan should be obtained to look for skeletal metastases, and radiographs and CT scans of the chest should be done to search for pulmonary metastases; the lungs are the most common sites of metastases.
  • CT scan may be helpful in differentiating osteosarcoma from myositis ossificans or an osteochondroma. The ossification in myositis ossificans is more mature at the periphery of the lesion, whereas the center of osteosarcoma is more heavily ossified.
  • Treatment:
    • It is highly radio-resistant tumor and ideally, treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. GCT. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone with soap bubble appearance. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). Curettage and stripping of the cavity is the treatment of choice.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.

questions.text: Earliest sign of compartment syndrome of leg is:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on passive stretch

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • In compartment syndrome the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling or numbness. Paresthesia, tingling or numbness occur in the late stages.

 

Option D. Pulselessness. It is also the late feature. Presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first sign of compartment syndrome is the pain and resistance to the passive stretch of the distal-most joint of the extremity.

questions.text: A patient presents with tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum. Identify the lesion. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bankart’s lesion

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations.
  • In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule, where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.
  • In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula.
  • This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion.
  • Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

  • This result in anterior instability of the shoulder joint due to the loss of the normal mechanisms, such as the block effect of the labrum, concavity compression mechanism of the rotator cuff, and function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament.
  • Lesions of the glenoid labrum are most commonly the result of traumatic anterior shoulder dislocation with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs lesion. A Hill-Sachs lesion is an osseous defect or "dent" of the postero-supero-lateral humeral head that occurs in association with anterior instability or dislocation of the glenohumeral joint. It is often associated with a Bankart lesion of the glenoid. This lesion is caused by an anterior shoulder dislocation which causes a humeral head impression fracture. The posterolateral aspect of the humeral head impacts on the anterior glenoid in the dislocated position, causing shoulder instability. If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair. They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum is called Bankart’s lesion, which is caused due to traumatic anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was taken to a trauma centre after suffering an accident. An X-ray of her pelvis was taken, and the image below demonstrates an intracapsular fracture neck of femur. In this instance, what is the management?  (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed reduction + internal fixation 

 

  • Intracapsular neck of femur fractures (# NOF) occur within the capsule of the hip joint.

  • The blood supply to femoral head travels in a retrograde direction via the capsule. So, any fracture within the capsule could likely damage the blood supply.  

  • Closed reduction and internal fixation method is favored in younger patients to preserve their natural hip joint.

  • In younger, active patients, the primary aim is always to save their own femoral head and avoid the need for joint replacement if possible. CRIF allows the fracture to heal, maintaining the patient's natural anatomy and biomechanics.

  • Intracapsular femoral neck fractures increases the risk of AVN of the femoral head. While the initial injury itself can compromise blood supply, a precise and anatomical reduction of the fracture fragments is crucial to potentially restore or optimize blood flow to the femoral head, thereby reducing the risk of AVN. CRIF, if successful, can achieve this without further disturbing the soft tissues and remaining blood supply around the fracture.

  • CRIF involves smaller incisions compared to ORIF, potentially leading to less soft tissue disruption, less blood loss, and a quicker initial recovery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemiarthroplasty: This is recommended in patients > 65 years of age with displaced fractures, lower functional demands, or pre-existing hip arthritis.

 

Option B. ORIF: ORIF is often preferred for younger and more active individuals where preserving the femoral head is a priority. While ORIF is also a valid treatment, closed reduction is often attempted first to minimize surgical trauma. If a closed reduction is not possible, then an open reduction may be necessary. Open reduction involves a larger incision and more disruption of the soft tissues around the hip joint which can potentially compromise the precarious blood supply to the femoral head, which is already at risk in an intracapsular fracture. ORIF is usually reserved for cases where closed reduction attempts fail. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a young patient, usually < 65 years of age, the ideal treatment method for intracapsular femoral neck fractures is closed reduction and internal fixation using cancellous screws. 

  • CRIF saves the femoral head by providing stable fixation after reduction, minimizing additional trauma to the already compromised blood supply, and avoiding the long-term complications. 

  • ORIF is usually an option if CRIF fails, and hemiarthroplasty is reserved for older, less active individuals.

questions.text: Shown in image is an orthopedic procedure being performed. Identity the procedure? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy

 

INTRAOSSEOUS THERAPY 

 

  • Intraosseous access is a rapid and effective method to deliver fluids, medications, and blood products directly into the bone marrow when intravenous access is difficult or impossible, especially in emergency situations.
  • Interosseous therapy is most commonly used in pediatric patients but can also be used in adults. 
  • The procedure involves inserting a needle or catheter through the skin and into the bone, typically in the tibia or humerus bones.
  • A needle is inserted at 90° to the medial surface of the tibia, and it is connected to a tube, suggesting fluid administration or aspiration.
  • Some common indications for IO therapy include:
    • Cardiac arrest or other life-threatening emergencies
    • Severe dehydration or shock
    • Patients with difficult venous access, such as obese or severely dehydrated patients or patients with vascular access issues due to scarring, burns, or other injuries.
    • Emergency situations such as during disasters or mass casualty incidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intraosseous abscess drainage: A drainage procedure usually involves a larger incision or different type of instrument for effective drainage.


Option C. Diagnostic biopsy: A bone biopsy involves taking a tissue sample for pathological examination. While a needle is used, the setup with continuous tubing for fluid administration is not typical for a routine diagnostic biopsy.
 

Option D. Intraosseous cannulation for pain relief: Intraosseous (IO) cannulation is a rapid method to administer medications through the bone marrow cavity in a critically ill or an injured patient. The procedure is both safe and effective in children and adults. The preferred site for the creation of intraosseous (IO) access is usually the shin. A local anesthetic is injected into the shin. Next, a cannula is inserted into the shin until a popping sensation is felt. Once the attempt is successful, the cannula is connected to the intravenous (IV) infusion set, which is a collection of sterile devices designed to conduct fluids from the IV fluid container to a patient's venous system. Indications for IO access includes arrhythmias, severe haemorrhage, septic shock, respiratory failure, severe dehydration, diabetic ketoacidosis, and burns. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is gametocidal to all the species causing malaria? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Primaquine

 

Primaquine is gametocidal to all species causing malaria. It inhibits transmission of malaria. Artemisinin also have high gametocidal activity against all the species.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • Primaquine interferes with the mitochondrial electron transport chain in the parasite, leading to the death of gametocytes and hypnozoites (dormant liver forms in Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale).
  • By eliminating gametocytes, primaquine helps reduce the spread of malaria within a community.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: is primarily effective against the erythrocytic forms of Plasmodium species but does not have gametocidal activity against all species. It is not effective against the dormant liver forms or the gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Option C. Quinine: is effective against the asexual blood stages of Plasmodium species but lacks significant activity against the gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum. It does not have a broad gametocidal effect against all species.

 

Educational Objective

 

Primaquine is the antimalarial drug that is gametocidal to all Plasmodium species, making it essential for preventing the transmission of malaria and addressing relapses in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale infections.

questions.text: Like all the opioids, tramadol acts as an analgesic drug by stimulating mu opioid receptors. Apart from this, the additional analgesic mechanism of tramadol is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serotonin and nor-adrenaline reuptake inhibition

 

Tramadol is an atypical opioid analgesic that not only acts by stimulating mu opioid receptors, like other opioids, but also has an additional mechanism of action. This dual mechanism contributes to its analgesic effect.

 

  • Mu Opioid Receptor Agonism: Tramadol binds to mu opioid receptors, which are part of the body's endogenous pain relief system. Activation of these receptors leads to pain relief.
  • Serotonin and Noradrenaline Reuptake Inhibition: Unlike typical opioids, tramadol also inhibits the reuptake of serotonin (5-HT) and noradrenaline (NA). This increases the levels of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, enhancing their action. This mechanism activates the monoaminergic descending inhibitory pathways in the spinal cord, which further contributes to pain relief.

 

Due to its unique mechanism, tramadol's analgesic action is only partially reversed by naloxone, an opioid antagonist, indicating that non-opioid mechanisms also play a significant role in its pain-relieving effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anticholinergic: Tramadol does not have anticholinergic properties. Anticholinergic drugs block the action of acetylcholine in the brain and are not related to the analgesic mechanism of tramadol.

 

Option C. Antihistaminic: Tramadol does not act as an antihistamine. Antihistamines are used primarily to treat allergic reactions and have no significant role in pain relief through histamine receptor antagonism.

 

Option D. Serotonin and dopamine reuptake inhibition: While tramadol does inhibit serotonin reuptake, it does not inhibit dopamine reuptake significantly. Its main additional mechanism of analgesia is through the inhibition of serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tramadol provides pain relief not only through mu opioid receptor agonism but also by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and noradrenaline, thereby activating the descending inhibitory pain pathways in the spinal cord.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/504

choices.text: Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius
Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

questions.text: An old lady fell in the bathroom with an outstretched hand. She was managed conservatively. Later on, she developed the deformity as shown in the figure. Most likely fracture sustained was:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Fracture of the distal end of radius at its corticocancellous junction, is commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture.
  • It is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
    • Colles fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable and are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint acutely to allow for swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
